pgTitle: List of catastrophic collapses of broadcast masts and towers

rows.text: Place of Magdeburg Transmitter, Berlin, Germany
Two towers snapped off 25 metres above ground
Partial destruction of a guyed mast under construction
Replaced by new mast of same height
Tower buckled at 2/3 of height. Tower carried radials on its top although it was not designed for them.
Replaced by 704ft (214 m) tall mast radiator
The collapsing mast also destroyed the transmitter building. 6 persons were killed.
Mast collapsed during guy wire tension testing
Replaced with 609.3 m tower which collapsed in 1997
Replaced with a temporary Antenna and moved to Yucuribampo Hill
Storm: high winds causing oscillations in the mast structure
collapse due to plane collision with guy wire
Replaced by 330.4 m free-standing concrete tower
Collapsed because of removal of load-bearing diagonals during FM antenna installation.
Multi-station tower supporting antennas of TV stations WDBO-TV, WFTV, and WMFE-TV, and radio stations WDBO-FM and WDIZ-FM – two workers on tower killed

1709 feet HAAT. Erected November 17, 1964. Had elevator, RCA Travelling Wave pylon antenna for Channel 12 (System M), land mobile antennas, all lost. RCA contractor for erection, Stainless subcontractor. No definitive cause ever found for collapse. Speculation of "galloping guy lines" (mechanical standing waves in one of the guys), causing stress-to-failure in the guys due to rapidly alternating strain.
Ice - The strain snapped 2-inch coupling bolts (24 of them) that joined the 2nd and 3rd sections.
In August 1969 - This tower was 1 of 3 tallest structures in the Northern Hemisphere and transmitter radiated the most powerful UHF-TV signal in the world. TV channel 14 (470-476MHz)
Ice - Same ice storm that toppled WJJY. Upper section of antenna broke loose and fell through the guy wires.
WAND and WJJY used the same RCA UHF antennas, mfg in 1969. TV channel 17 (488-494MHz)
Pinnacle with broadcasting antennas fell down, height afterwards 274 metres
Guy melted as result of high electric field strength, storm at same time made mast collapse

Total collapse during installation of 6-ton FM antenna on new 1800ft. tower. 5 technicians killed, 3 on the hoist and 2 on the tower. Determined insufficient sized bolts on the makeshift lifting lug extension failed. The falling debris severed one of the tower's guy wires which caused the tower to whip back and forth and collapse, video here.
Tallest ever mast aboard any ship; replaced by horizontal wire antenna between two shorter masts
Unusually heavy ice concentrated at top predominantly on one side of towers caused asymmetrical load. Dislodged essentially as one piece during rapid warming; sudden unloading caused dynamic failure.

Freezing rain, accompanied at time with thunder, coated the city of Duluth with as much as 6 inches of ice. The 850-foot WDIO-TV tower was toppled as winds gusted to 40 mph, buffeting the heavily ice-covered tower. The tower fell onto a nearby utility line which provided power to the remainder of Duluth’s television and FM radio stations, and all but one AM radio station. Telephone and power lines snapped leaving Duluth and many northeastern Minnesota communities with utility services for 24 hours. The DNR reported that four million pine trees were damaged or destroyed. - NOAA NWS Duluth, MN
Rebuilt by LeBlanc Tower of Canada
Fatigue failure of the eyebolt head in a compression cone insulator on structural guy caused swing-in damage, which resulted in structural collapse
3 died when tower collapsed in moderate wind gust
One killed, 2 injured when workers failed to install temporary braces
Three killed - temporary braces failed during HDTV antenna upgrade
3 died when medical helicopter hit guy wire in clear weather and crashed
Guyed steel lattice mast carrying a T-antenna
One World Trade Center broadcast tower
Tower was destroyed as a result of a terrorist attack in which a commercial airliner rammed into the side of the building causing it and the broadcast tower to collapse under its own weight.
Two workers killed, 3 injured on ground
Replacement Tower constructed shortly thereafter. Also knocked Clarke County, AL Sheriff's Office off the air (KWO611)
Temporary replacement mast constructed shortly thereafter. New permanent mast entered full service in February 2006.
Under construction. Also destroyed transmitter building. Was planned for a height of 1,036ft (315.77 m).

400-foot transmitter tower located on Averil Peak, NY completely collapsed as a result of heavy amounts of ice and snow from the April 2007 Nor'easter. Partially damaged the transmitter building at the base. New tower erected and back in service Oct, 9 2007.
Also damaged transmitter building and doppler radar.
300ft. section lost from top of tower
Wind gust reportedly caused the mast to collapse during a severe storm
Guyed steel tube mast on concrete tower
Tubular steel superstructure collapsed, new steel lattice superstructure constructed (2012) on top of existing concrete base tower
Pinnacle and upper sections fell down
Houston public safety radio tower, 5850 Teague Road, Houston, TX, USA
